UNC beats James Madison in season opener

  • By Alex Barinka and Andrew Dye
  • Multimedia Journalists
Sep. 03 3:34 pm
  • 18775no commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2011%2F09%2F03%2Ftar-heels-take-on-james-madison-in-football-season-opener%2F18775%2FUNC+beats+James+Madison+in+season+opener2011-09-03+19%3A34%3A29Alex+Barinkahttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D18775
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Reesenews is live-blogging the UNC football season opener against James Madison University. We are posting original reporting and photos, and updates from other news outlets and social media.

With the new Blue Zone filling up and the student section packed with Carolina Blue, the Tar Heel football team takes the field to face James Madison University in the season opener.

James Madison wins the coin toss and the Tar Heels will receive the kick off. It’s game time, folks.

First Quarter

(11:02) Bryn Renner, no. 2, completes a 34-yard pass to Dwight Jones, 83, for the first Carolina touchdown of the season. The offensive drive began with an 18-yard kick-off return by true freshman T.J. Thorpe to the 37 yard line.

Renner, a sophomore, had completed only two career passes as quarterback before today’s game. This year he will be filling the shoes of former UNC quarterback T.J. Yates who set more than 40 school records and led the Tar Heels to the three straight bowl games.

Freshman Wide Receiver Dwight Jones, no. 83, celebrates after receiving the first touchdown pass of the season. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

(4:41) Carolina scores its second touchdown of the game with a 12 play, 27-second drive as Giovani Bernard runs a 12-yard route into the end zone. Score: UNC 14, JMU 0 with about four minutes remaining in the quarter.

Giovani Bernard, tailback no. 26, and Ryan Houston, tailback no. 32, celebrate after a play. (Daniel Turner, reesenews)

With a minute left in the half Quinton Coples, no. 90, ends the James Madison drive with a sack at the 45 yard-line.

In the last play of the first quarter, Renner completes a pass Erik Highsmith, no. 88, for a 37-yard gain to the 19 yard line. Renner finishes out the first quarter of his first career start having completed all six pass attempts for 113 yards.

Junior Widereceiver Erik Highsmith, no. 88, celebrates after a catch for a 37-yard Tar Heel gain. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

At the end of the first quarter, UNC has racked up 15 plays for 153 yards against JMU’s 12 plays for 26 yards.

Sophomore Quarterback Bryn Renner, no. 2, runs the ball during the first quarter against James Madison. (Daniel Turner, reesenews)

Second Quarter

(14:32) Ryan Houston, senior tailback no. 32, scores his nineteenth career touchdown to extend the Tar Heels’ lead. Senior Kicker Casey Barth, no. 11, scored the extra point to bring the score to UNC 21, JMU 0.

Senior Tailback Ryan Houston, no. 32, catches a throw from sophomore Quarterback Bryn Renner, no. 2. (Daniel Turner, reesenews)

With less than nine minutes left in the first quarter, Renner throws his first incomplete pass of the game as JMU’s Dean Marlowe, no. 16, intercepts a pass at the 12 yard line.

Safety Dean Marlowe, no. 16, intercepts a pass as Devon Ramsay, full back no. 45, looks on. (Daniel Turner, reesenews)

(2:37) James Madison scores its first touchdown with a 47-yard reception in the longest play of the game for either team. In three plays, JMU Quarterback Justin Thorpe, no. 7, threw the scoring pass to Wide Receiver Daniel Brown, no. 10.

Justin Thorpe, quaterback no. 7, throws the ball during a JMU offensive drive while UNC's Defensive Tackle Tydreke Powell, no. 91 defends the pass. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

(1:05) The Tar Heels counter with a 14-yard touchdown run by Bernard to finish a 67-yard offensive drive.

Giovani Bernard, tailback no. 26, celebrates a touchdown in the season opener against James Madison. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

At the half, UNC leads James Madison 28-7 in the first game of the season. Some key numbers from the half:

  • UNC has completed 35 offensive plays for 292 yards while JMU has 26 offensive plays for 158 yards.
  • UNC rushed a total of 18 plays for a gain of 96 yards, with Bernard carrying the ball for 59 of them. Houston ran the ball for a total gain of 36 yards in the half.
  • In 17 attempts, UNC’s Renner has thrown 16 catches for 196 yards and one interception. His longest throw of the game? The 37 yard pass to Highsmith.
  • On the receiving end for the Tar Heels, Dwight Jones has 95 yards for the half and Highsmith has 45 yards.
  • Tre Boston, no. 10, and Zach Brown, no. 47, lead the Tar Heels in tackles with four unassisted and one assisted tackle each.

Third Quarter

(4:49) After an 18 play drive as far as the 5-yard line, UNC’s Zach Brown sacks JMU Quarterback Thorpe for a loss of six yards to the 14-yard line. Cameron Starke kicks a field goal for James Madison to bring the score to UNC 28, JMU 10.

Tar Heel Erik Highsmith, wide receiver no. 88, is taken down by Dukes' Vidal Nelson, linebacker no. 6. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

(4:25) UNC’s Devon Ramsay, fullback no. 45, leaves the field with a left-knee injury to be replaced by Curtis Byrd, no. 38. Ramsay will not return to the game.

(1:30) With a 15-yard pass from Renner to Wilson, the third quarter ends with the Tar Heels on the 5-yard line. Renner has thrown for 224 yards and completed 18 of 19 passes.

Tar Heel Quarterback Bryn Renner, no. 2, looks to pass down the field during the first game of the season against James Madison. (Andrew Dye, reesenews)

Fourth Quarter

(14:02) Bryn Renner scores his first career rushing touchdown from the 1-yard line, followed by a successful extra point by Barth, to bring the score to UNC 35, JMU 10.

(10:27) Carolina leads James Madison in offensive yards by 165 yards with a total of 365 yards as the Tar Heels continue an offensive drive from the 32-yard line.

Ryan Houston, tail back no. 32, rushed for 36 yards in the first three quarters.

(8:29) Renner throws a 21-yard touchdown pass to Dwight Jones, his second scoring reception of the game, to end a 52-yard drive. UNC tops JMU 42-10. The touchdown was Jones’second score of the game and ninth reception for 116 yards.
With his fourteenth consecutive completion, Renner tied the UNC record for consecutive completed pass attempts. Renner matched Kevin Anthony with his performance against Wake Forest University in 1985 and Jason Stanicek with his game against N.C. State University in 1992.

Donte Paige-Moss, defensive end no. 98, tackles James Madison's Justin Thorpe, quarterback no. 7, for a loss. (Daniel Turner, reesenews)

And that’s all folks. North Carolina tops James Madison 42-10 in the season opener. Stay tuned for performance highlights.

After the final whistle

  • Tar Heel Quarterback Bryn Renner, who completed 22 of 23 passes or 95.7 percent of his throws, set a school record for the highest completion percentage in a game. This finished just short of the NCAA record of 95.8 percent of passes completed set by Tennessee’s Tee Martin against South Carolina in 1998. Renner threw for a total of 277 yards and two touchdowns.
  • Dwight Jones caught nine of Renner’s passes to lead the Tar Heel receiving squad with 116 yards and two touchdowns. Erik Highsmith caught four passes for 47 yards, Ryan Houston had three receptions for 36 yards and Christian Wilson had two catches for 37 yards.
  • Complementing the passing game, Giovani Bernard, a red-shirt freshman running back, scored two touchdowns and rushed for 64 yards and averaged 7.1 yards per carry for nine possessions. Ryan Houston had sixteen carries for 59 yards and A.J. Blue ran the ball five times for 35 yards.
  • For the Tar Heels defense, Zach Brown finished out the game with five unassisted tackles, one assisted tackle and one sack. Tre Boston finished with four unassisted tackles and one assisted tackle.
